title: Repetitive Group Notifications
text: Please fix notifications from groups that are constantly grouping recent posts into the same highlight notification. Every time a group has a new post, I receive this “[Group name] has 5 new posts. Here’s one: ‘…..’“ along with the profile picture of whoever created the post. But the notification just repeats the same older post with the same profile picture every time, without notifying what a new post actually says. I want to be notified when there is a new post in the group, but I don’t want to see it as “[Group name] has 5 new posts.” Plus, when I click the notification, it takes me to the page with that same old post from the same person that could be 2, 3, 4 or 5 days old by now. I found that when I refresh the group’s page, it will reorder to show Most relevant/Newest activity, so then I do see the most recent post that’s actually triggering the notification. However the alerts should still be fixed so that each new post is getting its own individual notification rather than being grouped with and overshadowed by older, irrelevant content.

title: Meh
text:
Facebook's blatant disregard for user privacy is nothing short of appalling. It's clear that the platform's primary concern is not the well-being of its users, but rather the financial gains it can reap from their personal data.
Time and time again, Facebook has demonstrated its willingness to exploit users' information for its own benefit, with little regard for the potential harm this can cause. The company's repeated failures to adequately protect user data have led to countless privacy breaches and data leaks, leaving users vulnerable to identity theft, cybercrime, and other serious threats.
Moreover, Facebook's opaque and convoluted privacy policies make it nearly impossible for users to understand what information the company is collecting, how it's being used, and who it's being shared with. This lack of transparency is unacceptable, and it leaves users feeling helpless and exposed.
To make matters worse, Facebook has shown little remorse for its actions, and has done little to rectify the damage it has caused. The company's half-hearted attempts at addressing privacy concerns feel more like lip service than a genuine effort to do better.
Overall, if you value your privacy and security, it's best to steer clear of Facebook. The platform's track record when it comes to protecting user data is abysmal, and it's clear that the company has no intention of changing its ways.

title: The best and worst of humanity
text:
Social platforms are what you make them. 
I try to purposefully follow informative, uplifting content…spanning from keeping up with global non-profits, to births and engagements of friends, as well as participate in support groups and advocacy groups around the world. All of this with the hope of growing and challenging myself, as well as participating in away that bares witness my values and intentions. So grateful to be connected across oceans with people I hold dear too. Messenger keeps us closer.  Texting, calling, and simply keeping up,… is such a privilege. 
I have also seen others use it for the opposite. Between Instagram and Facebook, (often stranger to stranger) it is difficult to witness the depravity of human nature around the world. Lack of basic respect and common decency as well as the slow death of nuance in conversation. People forget each other’s humanity and vulnerability. Especially during US election years, war in the Middle East, and other polarising similar seasons — it’s that much more difficult to avoid. 
When that heaviness is too much, boundaries are drawn. I choose to take breaks from some or all of it.

title: Disappointed with Facebook's Integration of Reels in the Watch Section
text: I am extremely disappointed with the recent integration of Reels into the Watch section. In my opinion, this addition has only served to frustrate and dilute the overall video-watching experience. First and foremost, the Watch section was initially intended for videos, and it excelled in providing a streamlined platform for users to discover and enjoy a wide variety of video content. However, the introduction of Reels has cluttered the once-clean interface with short, repetitive snippets that lack substance and relevance. I find it frustrating to scroll through a mix of meaningful videos and mindless Reels, as it hinders my ability to discover the type of content I am genuinely interested in. The inclusion of Reels in the Watch section feels redundant. Reels already have their dedicated space within the main Facebook feed, where users can easily access and engage with this specific form of content. Merging them into the Watch section only serves to create confusion and diminishes the overall quality of the video-watching experience. It seems that Facebook's decision to merge these two features was made without considering the negative impact it would have on user satisfaction.
